holidays.name: Mole Day
holidays.description: Celebrate the chemist’s favorite number—Avogadro's Number (6.022 x 10^23)! It’s a quirky day for chemistry geeks and students everywhere to appreciate the mole, a unit used to count particles like atoms and molecules.
holidays.origin: Mole Day was unofficially started by chemistry teachers in the early 1980s in the United States as a fun way to engage students with chemistry concepts.
holidays.funFact: Mole Day celebrations often include ‘Avocado’ references, since ‘avocado’ sounds like Avogadro! Some parties even serve guacamole as a punny treat.

holidays.name: National Nut Day
holidays.description: A nutty day to celebrate all kinds of nuts—cashews, almonds, walnuts, and pecans. It’s a crunchy holiday honoring these delicious and nutritious snacks.
holidays.origin: National Nut Day was created by the National Day Calendar organization to encourage healthy snacking and to recognize nuts' role in nutrition and cooking.
holidays.funFact: Despite their name, peanuts are actually legumes, not true nuts — a fun botanical twist for nut lovers!

holidays.name: Capoeira Day
holidays.description: Celebrate the Brazilian martial art that’s part dance, part fight, and all rhythm! Capoeira Day honors this Afro-Brazilian tradition with music, acrobatics, and cultural pride.
holidays.origin: Observed in Brazil, October 23 marks the anniversary of the first capoeira school opening, highlighting its unique heritage blending combat, dance, and music.
holidays.funFact: Capoeira was originally developed by enslaved Africans in Brazil as a form of self-defense disguised as dance to avoid detection by colonial authorities.

holidays.name: Mickey Mouse Day
holidays.description: Remember the big cheese himself, Mickey Mouse! October 23 marks Mickey’s birthday, commemorating his first public appearance in the cartoon 'Steamboat Willie' in 1928.
holidays.origin: Created by Walt Disney, Mickey Mouse's debut on October 23, 1928, revolutionized animation and created an iconic character beloved worldwide.
holidays.funFact: Mickey Mouse was the first cartoon character to get a star on the Hollywood Walk of Fame in 1978.
